column3: I shall find some way of earning a living, and then I shall go and get a room for myself.'

column2: 'Now don't--now don't talk like that!' exclaimed her father, putting his hand on her.
column3: 'Now don't-now don't talk like that!' exclaimed her father, putting his hand on her.

column2: 'You shall do what else you like, my girl, but don't talk about goin' away from me.
column3: 'You shall do what else you like, my girl, but don't talk about goin' away from me.

column2: That's the one thing as I couldn't bear. I ain't so young as I was, and I've had things as was hard to go through--I mean when the mother died and--and other things at that time.
column3: That's the one thing as I couldn't bear. I ain't so young as I was, and I've had things as was hard to go through-I mean when the mother died and-and other things at that time.

column2: Let you an' me stay by each other whilst we may, my girl.
column3: Let you an' me stay by each other whilst we may, my girl.

column2: You know it was always you as I thought most of, and I want to keep you by me--I do, Clara.
column3: You know it was always you as I thought most of, and I want to keep you by me-I do, Clara.

column2: You won't speak about goin' away?'
column3: You won't speak about goin' away?'

column2: She remained mute.
column3: She remained mute.

column2: Shadows from the firelight rose and fell upon the walls of the half-darkened room.
column3: Shadows from the firelight rose and fell upon the walls of the half darkened room.

column2: It was a cloudy morning; every now and then a gust flung rain against the window.
column3: It was a cloudy morning; every now and then a gust flung rain against the window.

column2: 'If you went,' he continued, huskily, 'I should be afraid myself.
column3: 'If you went,' he continued, huskily, 'I should be afraid myself.

column2: I haven't told you.
column3: I haven't told you.

column2: I didn't behave as I'd ought have done to the poor mother, Clara; I got into drinkin' too much; yes, I did.
column3: I didn't behave as I'd ought have done to the poor mother, Clara; I got into drinkin' too much; yes, I did.

column2: I've broke myself off that; but if you was to leave me--I've had hard things to go through.
column3: I've broke myself off that; but if you was to leave me-I've had hard things to go through.

column2: Do you know the Burial Club broke up just before she died?
column3: Do you know the Burial Club broke up just before she died?

column2: I couldn't get not a ha'penny!
column3: I couldn't get not a ha'penny!

column2: A lot o' the money was stolen.
column3: A lot o' the money was stolen.

column2: You may think how I felt, Clara, with her lyin' there, and I hadn't got as much as would pay for a coffin.
column3: You may think how I felt, Clara, with her lyin' there, and I hadn't got as much as would pay for a coffin.

column2: It was Sidney Kirkwood found the money--he did!
column3: It was Sidney Kirkwood found the money-he did!

column2: There was never man had as good a friend as he's been to me; I shall never have a chance of payin' what I owe him.
column3: There was never man had as good a friend as he's been to me; I shall never have a chance of payin' what I owe him.

column2: Things is better with me now, but I'd rather beg my bread in the streets than you should go away.
column3: Things is better with me now, but I'd rather beg my bread in the streets than you should go away.

column2: Don't be afraid, my dearest.
column3: Don't be afraid, my dearest.

column2: I promise you nobody shan't come near.
column3: I promise you nobody shan't come near.

column2: You won't mind Mrs. Eagles; she's very good to the children.
column3: You won't mind mrs Eagles; she's very good to the children.

column2: But I must keep you near to me, my poor girl!'
column3: But I must keep you near to me, my poor girl!'

column2: Perhaps sit was that word of pity--though the man's shaken voice was throughout deeply moving.
column3: Perhaps sit was that word of pity-though the man's shaken voice was throughout deeply moving.

column2: For the first time since the exultant hope of her life was blasted, Clara shed tears.
column3: For the first time since the exultant hope of her life was blasted, Clara shed tears.

column2: CHAPTER XXVIII
column3: CHAPTER twenty eight

column2: THE SOUP-KITCHEN
column3: THE SOUP KITCHEN

column2: With the first breath of winter there passes a voice half-menacing, half-mournful, through all the barren ways and phantom-haunted refuges of the nether world.
column3: With the first breath of winter there passes a voice half menacing, half mournful, through all the barren ways and phantom haunted refuges of the nether world.

column2: Too quickly has vanished the brief season when the sky is clement, when a little food suffices, and the chances of earning that little are more numerous than at other times; this wind that gives utterance to its familiar warning is the vaunt-courier of cold and hunger and solicitude that knows not sleep.
column3: Too quickly has vanished the brief season when the sky is clement, when a little food suffices, and the chances of earning that little are more numerous than at other times; this wind that gives utterance to its familiar warning is the vaunt courier of cold and hunger and solicitude that knows not sleep.

column2: Will the winter be a hard one?
column3: Will the winter be a hard one?

column2: It is the question that concerns this world before all others, that occupies alike the patient workfolk who have yet their home unbroken, the strugglers foredoomed to loss of such scant needments as the summer gifted them withal, the hopeless and the self-abandoned and the lurking creatures of prey.
column3: It is the question that concerns this world before all others, that occupies alike the patient workfolk who have yet their home unbroken, the strugglers foredoomed to loss of such scant needments as the summer gifted them withal, the hopeless and the self abandoned and the lurking creatures of prey.

column2: To all of them the first chill breath from a lowering sky has its voice of admonition; they set their faces; they sigh, or whisper a prayer, or fling out a curse, each according to his nature.
column3: To all of them the first chill breath from a lowering sky has its voice of admonition; they set their faces; they sigh, or whisper a prayer, or fling out a curse, each according to his nature.
